katewarters: So grateful you posted this today. I needed to hear it badly! I had knee surgery last week and recovery is hard. The rehab exercises make me feel so weak and incapable. Even moving my body around or up and down stairs on crutches is tiring and uncomfortable. And when it feels hard, I am inclined to be angry at myself, to tell myself I deserve the pain and challenge, and to see it as my penance for being fat. But you are right. That’s just my own internalized fatphobia. This may be hard, but my body can do the hard work and I deserve to let myself be positive and encouraging as I heal. Best wishes to you and your continued journey to well being. Thank you!
kelseybearbaby: I literally just did this. I got chronically ill for 2 months before my boyfriend finally made me go. The first doc. A damn bitch dismissed me completely. Saw me for 30secs before weight loss surgery/pills came out her mouth. And when I said I don’t want to talk about that. I’m not interested. I was rude for getting an attitude because she CONTINUED to push me to talk about it. She had the audacity to say. Sweetie don’t get an attitude about it. Took me 2 more docs before I FINALLY found treatment that worked.
ellytheknight: I'm so glad you were able to work through the negative self-talk. I know it can be rough.
singingbron: Thank you so much for your post and for your vulnerability in putting this out into the world. I've spent years avoiding doctors for fear of being told to "just lose weight". At the start of this year when I had some blood tests done, I was genuinely terrified I'd find out that I was diabetic because I'd spent so long not taking proper care of myself. When it turned out I WASN'T diabetic I realised that the reason I thought I would be was because I believed I deserved it, that it would be the fitting punishment for the "crime" of being in a body my size. I was so sad to discover that I'd been thinking that way about my body, so this year has been a process of ACTUALLY looking after myself instead. Now I have an amazing HAES-supportive doctor, dietitian and therapist, as well as a pretty awesome dentist, ob/gyn and optometrist... all the health providers, lol! I think of them as Team Bron - I know they're all on my side and helping me be the healthiest version of me in the body I have, not the body that diet culture wants me to have. P.S. Your yoga mat is pretty! (And so are you!) <3 :)
randallsixx13: Self acceptance in these cases is suicide.
awgir: Damn that soo impressive and positive. U give me some hope for better days 💕
victorialoses100: This happened to me too. I was so in denial of needing desperate help with my pain and thought they would just tell me to lose weight. copykat93: @everydamndayfitness would love to hear your take on this
moodydudey: Body positivity is tough. Coming to acceptance of self is a constant challenge regardless of weight. I recently lost 100 lbs for health reasons (familial stroke risk, borderline diabetes, unpredictable high BP, sleep apnea, autoimmune disease compounded by extra weight, to name a few). I fought listening to my doctors. My husband loves & accepts my body at whatever size. I had to come to a place of peace to decide I wanted to live the longest life possible. I’ve been really small, really big & everywhere in between and I’ve never loved my body at any weight. So I decided to focus on my health instead & feel so much better. Funny thing is, I see beauty in all sizes & shapes in everyone except myself, which is why I love your confidence. Do what you need to for yourself, not because of pressure from doctors to lose weight or from fans to keep weight. Follow your own instincts about what your body & soul need and figure out how to love yourself no matter where you are. Your beauty has nothing to do with your outer shell. Your body is just a garage to hold your car & your car will always be beautiful and shiny 🌟
kimiecakez: Thank you for posting this message, and being real that self love is a daily struggle sometimes.
worthyfigures: Addressing this issue at @fgt_fatcamp this weekend of how to be an advocate for yourself in health care. Getting extra inspiration from this post! Thank you for your vulnerability in sharing.
mayakern: Ohh I feel this a lot 😭

kayleighann88: Glad you could ignore the voice and carry on 💛 x
meg.sells: Man, I had to convince doctors for half a year that my LEUKEMIA symptoms were real and not just me being fat. Advocating for yourself is scary, hard, and exhausting. cloudydacie: I hateee hate hate going to the doctor for the same reason. I’m actually switching doctors because of it. The most important thing for me to remember when I go in is to advocate for myself. I even write out lists of topics to focus on of I need to so I can stay on task and keep her from straying and bringing up my weight when I came in to talk about totally separate issues. I try to be vocal and assert my power over my body from the beginning so my doctors know what I’m about. But all of that is hard asf and you and all of my fellow fats who fight the anxiety and go to the doctor are so brave and I want us all to keep doing it and refusing to put up with abuse from medical professionals ❤️❤️
jgrundy0926: I almost bled to death earlier this year because I put off going to my doctor in fear of being fat. People say “just go to the dr” but it’s not that simple when you struggle with your weight.
the_tao_of_tara: I am struggling with this lately in a major way. I feel like even the chairs in a doctor's office are judging me. "Maybe if i was smaller, I could fit in this chair". It's awful. scarletmay13: Your hairstyle and you are so adorable, omg!!!!!!!
happily__me_: I have struggled with the same put off going to the doctor, stopped taking medication and I ended up in the hospital. I know I’ll never be thin and I’m okay with that because I love me, all that matters is I’m healthy, pages like yours has helped me so much with my body image and I am grateful for you 🥰
kylaaflynn: All doctors are going to tell you it's not healthy to be over weight , it's just science . But you can find an amazing doctor if you really look , from my experience women doctors are the best . My general practitioner Dr. Is a woman and she's seriously amazing . Takes every concern I have seriously and it's like talking to a friend every time I ask for advice or have an issue . All you have to do is look for a doctor and keep looking until you find someone that you are comfortable speaking to about anything and is also sensitive to your needs . Please though don't think all doctors are insensitive a-holes my doctor before this was a man and he was an asshole .
ashleetaylorwilson: Work. I just started working after being a stay at home mom and I work at amazon such a fast pace environment. I gained a little over 100 in the year and the past couple of days I've been thinking "should I even do this" "I'm sure everyone thinks i cant do it" but I can keep up with everyone body type I work with and its exhilarating. Its makes me proud in myself.
realdeal_doc_dooley: We (healthcare providers) have SO damn far to go 😕 ... one of the symptoms of depression is a change in appetite ... when I ask the question [have u noticed any changes in your appetite?] about 90% of the time the person responds with a negative comment about their weight or shape ... I have to reframe and really let the patient know that I am not asking about weight (or judging their weight) ... but really want to know how their appetitive has been ... because irrespective of weight or size changes in appetite might be a part of changing or unstable mood or be part of disordered eating ... as a small fat with the privilege of being a healthcare provider I have the privilege of not being dismissed very often ... I agree with asking other fat folks what providers they have had good experiences with ... ❤️💛❤️
yumaratz: I am so happy that you overcame your fear and went to the doctor. Doctors by and large are not fun and it is sometimes hard to remember that you are in control of your health and treatment.

danielle.bex: I'm struggling a lot with going to doctors. The thought of paying someone to dismiss my concerns makes me sick. I'm such an up front and confrontational person but when it comes to my health the voice in my head says "no that's on you". I know it's not true but if I go to the doctor and they reinforce that perspective... I die a little inside. I just want the world to be better already.
mandycreasy: I've ignored my health for so long and am terrified to address any of it. Thank you for sharing this. It's reassuring to see I'm not the only one who struggles.
totoatoz: I have multiple diagnosis but still have people treat me like it’s my fault. And I am my own worst enemy. I have been self conscious my entire life. Have never been able to get past it. I hope you can. You deserve better 😘
theformermissrappe: I’m a type 1 diabetic. During my pregnancy my specialist would constantly confuse me as gestational or a type 2 because of my size. Very annoying and potentially dangerous. The bias has the potential to kill people.
cgrimm: I WAS JUST TALKING ABOUT THIS TODAY! Sorry for yelling. I just get this
samanthasweet64: I can so relate. I have an invisible illness and when I am really sick, doctors generally just see my sweet plus- sizedness rather than listening to my symptoms. I learned that my best advocate is...me. Proud of you for advocating for yourself!!
mriafdez: You're such a wonderful soul, i just thought you should know that 💙
nerdy_nettie: @fatgirlflow something I always ask my doctors or ANY medical personnel I come in contact with is this. “What would the course of action be if I was thin?” Usually they say “oh some labs/scans/tests/etc” to which I reply “great! Let’s do that!” It ensures that they are thorough, not being lazy doctors by writing it off as weight, and I am getting the care I need. Often we have found my issues are indeed NOT due to weight. Finding that if we were not thorough I could have become really ill. Hope the question I’ve shared with you helps you along your journey. ☺️💕
